editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: TO MY MOST DEARELY Beloved, and much honoured friends (how≈øoever dignified or di≈øtingui≈øhed) the Inhabitants of Plympton St. Mary, the increa≈øe of all ≈øaving grace, and everla≈øting bli≈ø≈øe.
div.p:
LOve among the Ancients was pourtrayed and ≈øhadowed out by, and under the image of a woman cloathed in a greene garment, having written in her forehead, Procul & Prop√®, afarre off, and neere at hand; in her brea≈øt, Mors & vita, life and death; in the hemme of her garment, Hyems & ae≈øtas, winter and ≈øummer; in her ≈øide, Vulnus apertum, an open wound, thorough which her heart within might be ≈øeen. My love to you (farre from me be all ba≈øe flattery and ≈øelfe-commendation) hath beene very fervent, like the love of women; greene, and never withering, alwayes fre≈øh and flouri≈øhing; not only while I was pre≈øent with you, but ≈øince
I have been ab≈øent from you, the ≈øen≈øe at lea≈øt of my love hath beene more abundant towards you: ≈øuch hath been my love to you, that you were in my heart to live and to dye with you: I could willingly in winter and in ≈øummer, in all changes, have continued your ≈øervant, as Jacob ≈øerved Labans flock in the heat and in the cold: My heart is open to you, as a Bridegroomes heart and hou≈øe is open to receive the Bride; and had your former beene like the la≈øt manife≈øtations of your love towards me, I am a≈ø≈øured all the proffers and per≈øwa≈øions of the world, ≈øhould never have drawne me from you. Great is the power and ≈øtrength of affection, with which faithfull Mini≈øters love the Lords people: as grace is more powerfull then nature, ≈øo is their love ≈øtronger then the love of nature: Non minus vos diligo (≈øaith Ambro≈øe) quos genui ex Evangelio, qu√†m ≈øi ≈øu≈øcepi≈ø≈øem conjugio; gratia quippe vehementior e≈øt ad diligendum qu√†m natura. I love you no le≈ø≈øe whom I have begotten by the Go≈øpel, then if I had begotten you in matrimoniall conjunction; becau≈øe grace hath more energy and vehemency in the way and worke of love, then nature. And in my unfained love, and as a pledge and te≈øtimony of my never-dying love, I have ≈øent you the≈øe papers, part of which is the la≈øt Legacy I had to be≈øtow upon you at the time of my departure from you: It is very u≈øefull for all Chri≈øtians to renew the memory of the pa≈øt labours of Gods me≈ø≈øengers.

Every good child de≈øires a copy of his Fathers
will, to ≈øee his Fathers love, to know his Fathers gift, to remember and ob≈øerve his Fathers charge and coun≈øell: Children within ≈øome few dayes after their Fathers death expect the receipt of their parents Legacie and bequeath; and loving children are ever very glad to accept, and very carefull to keep their parents la≈øt gift, though of ≈ølender worth: the la≈øt words of Gods Mini≈øters, our ≈øpirituall parents, doe commonly (like the words of dying men) take the deepe≈øt impre≈ø≈øion in their hearers. True Chri≈øtians thinke often, and put great price upon the la≈øt labours of Gods Mini≈øters: I therefore here pre≈øent unto you that which I publi≈øhed as my la≈øt mini≈øteriall Will and Te≈øtament among you, with ≈øome part of my poore labours ≈øince be≈øtowed on others, de≈øiring you, like loving children, to accept it; like provident and carefull children, to make the humble, true, and be≈øt u≈øe of it: A ≈ømall gift well u≈øed, proves many times an in≈øtrument of great inrichment.

Though I cea≈øe to be your Mini≈øter, and am now no more your In≈øtructer, yet I cannot cea≈øe to bee your true, though weake and unworthy, perhaps de≈øpi≈øed, friend: and as ointment and perfume (according to Solomon) rejoice the heart, ≈øo would I gladly by hearty coun≈øell, di≈øtill on you the drops of ≈øome friendly, ≈øome Chri≈øtian and ≈øpirituall ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe, to the rejoicing and revivement of your ≈øoules: and as iron ≈øharpens iron, ≈øo am I willing by ≈øome words of admonition, exhortation, and excitation, to ≈øharpen
and quicken your affections.

Let me therefore as a con≈øtant lover of your ≈øoules, and a carefull remembrancer of your welfare, intreat and per≈øwade you all, 1. To grow in the ≈øight and ≈øen≈øe of your ≈øinne: Beware of hardne≈ø≈øe, keepe your hearts ≈øoft and contrite, nouri≈øh and maintaine all tenderne≈ø≈øe in your con≈øciences: ≈øen≈øe of mi≈øery ≈øweetens mercy; the feeling of ≈øin breeds both the loathing and leaving of ≈øinne; mans ≈øight of his owne vilene≈ø≈øe, makes Chri≈øt very precious, and breeds a low opinion of all worldly excellencies. The Hart feeling within him the operation of the ≈øerpents poy≈øon, goes from the thornes and thickets and pa≈ø≈øeth over the greene and plea≈øant pa≈øtures, de≈øires nothing but the fountaine: ≈øen≈øe of the venome of ≈øinne and uncleanne≈ø≈øe, makes man go from the thornes and thickets of worldly cares and riches, and pa≈ø≈øe from the greene medowes of carnall plea≈øures, the ≈øoule being re≈øtle≈ø≈øe untill it comes to Chri≈øt Je≈øus the fountain of all ≈øpirituall refre≈øhments.

Secondly, take heed, deceive not your ≈øelves with ≈øhewes and ≈øhadowes in ≈øtead of ≈øub≈øtance, with a forme in ≈øtead of the power of godline≈ø≈øe: As the Poets fable it of Ixion imbracing a cloud in ≈øtead of Juno; or as mothers in ha≈øte ≈øomtimes catch at the ≈øwadling clothes, and leave the child behind them. It is very dangerous to ≈øtay and applaud our ≈øelves in the ceremony of Religion and godline≈øs, not taking with us the Lord Je≈øus, as ≈øometimes Mary and Jo≈øeph went on with
the multitude for company, and left Chri≈øt behind them: all religious ob≈øervations prove complementall, frivolous and fruitle≈ø≈øe, if in them we ≈øee not, ta≈øte not, receive not, enjoy not Chri≈øt: religious exerci≈øes are lo≈øt labours to the ≈øoule that gaines not the Lord Je≈øus.

Thirdly, Be truely meeke and humble, bee emptied of all opinion of your owne worth and wi≈øedome; this will make you wi≈øe unto ≈øalvation: He that is in the low pits and caves of the earth ≈øees the ≈øtarres in the firmament, when they who are on the tops of the mountaines di≈øcerne them not. Hee that is mo≈øt humble ≈øees mo≈øt of heaven: Bona e≈øt via humilitatis (≈øaith Bernard) qu√¢ veritas inquiritur, charitas acquiritur, & generationes ≈øapientiae percipiuntur. Good (≈øaith he) is the way of humility, whereby truth is ≈øearched out, charity is obtained, and the generations of wi≈ødome are perceived. Humility exalteth; he that is mo≈øt humble, is, and ≈øhalbe mo≈øt honourable. Mo≈øes was the meeke≈øt man on earth, and God made him the mo≈øt honourable, calling him up unto him≈øelfe in the mount, and making him the Leader of his people. Gedeon was very little in his own eyes, the lea≈øt of his fathers hou≈øe in his owne apprehen≈øion, and God marvellou≈øly exalted him, making him the deliverer of I≈ørael. As mans pride is attended with infamy, ≈øo is mans meekne≈ø≈øe waited on with glory. Vis magnus e≈ø≈øe? incipe ab imo: Wilt thou be great? begin from below, ≈øaith the Father. As the roots of the tree de≈øcend,
≈øo the branches a≈øcend: this makes the ≈øoule capable of grace, as the low grounds of water, and the broken earth of ≈øeed. God gives grace to the humble, as men poure liquor into an empty ve≈ø≈øell. The Altar under the Law was hollow, to receive the fire, the wood, and the ≈øacrifice: the heart of man under the Go≈øpel mu≈øt be humble, empty of all ≈øpirituall pride and ≈øelfe-conceit, to receive the fire of the ≈øpirit, and Je≈øus Chri≈øt, who offered him≈øelfe a ≈øacrifice for our ≈øinnes: this keeps the ≈øoule free from many darts of Satans ca≈øting, and ≈ønares of his ≈øpreading, as the low ≈øhrubs are free from many violent gu≈øts and bla≈øts of wind, which ≈øhake and rent the taller trees. I have read of one, that ≈øeeing in a vi≈øion many ≈ønares of the devill ≈øpread upon earth, he ≈øate downe and mourned, and ≈øaid within him≈øelfe, Quis pertran≈øiet i≈øta? Who ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe through the≈øe? whereunto he heard a voice an≈øwering, Humilitas pertran≈øiet, Humility ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe through them. The Divell hath lea≈øt power to fa≈øten a temptation on him that is mo≈øt humble: hee that hath a gracious mea≈øure of meekne≈ø≈øe is neither affected with Satans proffers, nor terrified with his threatnings: This makes man peaceable in conver≈øing with his brethren, fruitfull in well-doing, cheerfull in ≈øuffering, comfortable in every condition, con≈øtant in holy walking; this makes a man precious in the eyes of God, as a humble ≈øervant in the eyes of his Ma≈øter. Qui parvus e≈øt in reputatione propri√¢, magnus e≈øt in reputatione divin√¢, ≈øaith Gregory:
He that is little in his owne account, is great in Gods e≈øteeme. This makes the way and worke of man acceptable unto God, and al≈øo ≈øweetens and encrea≈øeth mans communion with God. If ever therefore you entend to enjoy Gods glorious and ble≈ø≈øed pre≈øence, labour for this humility and meekne≈ø≈øe.

Fourthly, Bee ≈øervent and unfained in your love to God, his truth, and his children: this will make your language very gracious. Amantium mos e≈øt, (≈øaith Chry≈øo≈øtome) ut amorem ≈øuum ≈øilentio tegere nequeunt: Lovers know not how to keepe ≈øilence; lovers of God are very full of gracious expre≈ø≈øions: this will make you liberal, you ≈øhall give your ≈øelves to God and the ≈øervice of his Saints, as the men of Macedonia did: this will make you patient in ≈øuffering, as Jacob in his ≈øervice for Rachel: this will make you frequent the hou≈øe of God with all alacrity, frequency, and diligence, as children their fathers hou≈øe and table: this will make you joyfull in hearing the word of God, as the Bride in hearing the voice of the Bridegroome: this will make you carefull, free and full in the ob≈øervation of Gods ≈øtatutes, as loving children in the ob≈øervation of their fathers precepts: this will make you diligent and rich in all good workes; the more man loves God, the more he ≈øtrives in all well-doing to glorifie God. Love, like fire, is not idle, but operative: Amor Dei (≈øaith Gregory) nunquam otio≈øus e≈øt; operatur enim magna ≈øi e≈øt; ≈øi ver√≤ operari renuit, amor non e≈øt:
The love of God (≈øaith he) is never idle; for if it is, it worketh great things; but if it refu≈øe to work, it is not love. Love makes the yoke of God ea≈øie, and his worke delightfull; it is only want of love that makes the commandement a burden: Tant√≤ magis delectat opus bonum, quant√≤ magis diligitur Deus ≈øummum & incommutabile bonum, ≈øaith Augu≈øtine: A good work ≈øo much the more delighteth, by how much the more God the chiefe≈øt and unchangable good is loved.

Love among ≈øome of the Ancients was re≈øembled to, and repre≈øented by the Sun: the Sunne inlightens the world; the more love the more light. Knowledge and love, like the water and the ice, beget each other; man loves God by knowing, and knows God by loving. God dwels in love, and where God is there is light: that mans light is darkne≈ø≈øe which is not attended with the love of God and his te≈øtimonies: the Sunne makes the earth fertile; he that loves God cannot be barren, his love makes him fruitfull in all well-doing: the Sunne is ≈øwift and con≈øtant in his motion; love makes man cheerfull, ≈øpeedy, and unwearied in running the race which God hath ≈øet before him: the Sunne is impa≈ø≈øible, love is patient and invincible, it endureth all things; no floods can drown it, no waters can quench it. Want of love and affection is the maine cau≈øe of mans apo≈øtacy and back-≈øliding: the Sunne ca≈øteth his beames upward and downward, to the Ea≈øt and to the We≈øt, to the North and to the South; Chri≈øtian
love cau≈øeth its beames to a≈øcend to God above, and to de≈øcend to man beneath; to our friends on the right hand, to our enemies on the left hand; to them that are in the ≈øtate or grace before us, to them th ‚Ä¢ t are in the ≈øtate of corruption behind us: love which is not in this ≈øen≈øe univer≈øall, is corrupt and carnall. The Sun beginning to a≈øcend in his circle, never goes back u ‚Ä¢ till he comes to the highe≈øt degree thereof: true love abhorres apo≈øtacy, a≈øcends to more perfection, and cea≈øeth not untill, like Eliahs fiery chariot, it hath carried the ≈øoule to heaven: If ever you meane to ≈øee and enjoy the God of love, labour for this love.

Fiftly, Be very ≈øerious, ≈øtudious, circum≈øpect, and carefull in all your walkings; ponder the path of your feet, like carefull travellers; con≈øider and weigh all your doings, let all your waies of the heart within, and worke without, be ordered aright, according the rule of Gods word; every motion of the ≈øoule is a ≈øtep to life or a ≈øtep to death; a ≈øtep towards heaven or toward hell: Mans labour and ≈øervice is temporall, his wages and recompence eternall; therfore as Zeuxes that famous Lymner, being demanded why he was ≈øo exact and ≈øerious, ≈øo long, ≈øo careful and curious in his workman≈øhip, an≈øwered, Diu pingo, quia aeternitati pingo; I am long in painting, becau≈øe I paint unto eternity. We all paint unto eternity; every one of our actions tends to an eternity of joyes or ≈øorrowes; all our temporall actions are as ≈øeeds of eternity ≈øowne by us: a
temporall ≈øeed an eternall harve≈øt: we ≈øpeak, we heare, we write, we read, we pray, we ≈øing, we conferre, we worke, we thinke unto eternity: how exact and ≈øerious ≈øhould we be in our ≈øhort walking, the end whereof is eternall! Vigilanti cur√¢ (≈øaith Gregory) per cuncta opera intentio nobis pen≈øanda e≈øt, ut nihil temporale in his quae agit appetat, ≈øed totam ≈øe in ≈øoliditate aeternitatis figat: The intention is thorough all our works to bee weighed with vigilant care, that in the things which it doth, it may de≈øire nothing temporall, but wholly fa≈øten it ≈øelfe on that which is eternall: hee that walkes not circum≈øpectly deprives him≈øelfe of an eternity of felicity, and ca≈øts him≈øelfe into an eternity of mi≈øery: better live ≈øtrictly for a time, then live mi≈øerably for ever; nay, bee a≈ø≈øured that even for the pre≈øent, there is more comfort in one dayes ≈øtrict walking with God, then in a thou≈øand dayes loo≈øe conver≈øing with men. Did men know the peace, joy, ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe, boldne≈ø≈øe, honour and triumph of holy walking, they would in≈øtantly and for ever abandon all di≈ø≈øolute living: heaven is the paradice of all joyes; he that in his holy walking commeth neare≈øt unto heaven, is doubtle≈ø≈øe of all men the mo≈øt joyfull. O ≈øay not then, as a man of noble blood and acute wit, but profane life, ≈øometime did, when being demanded what he thought of the au≈øtere life of the godly, and licentious life of the wicked, an≈øwered, Cum i≈øtis mallem vivere, cum illis mori mallem; I had rather live with the latter, I had rather dye with
the former. But as you de≈øire to dye the death of the righteous, ≈øo bee very ≈øolicitous and ≈øtudious, very vigilant and indu≈øtrious to live the life of the righteous: Never promi≈øe your ≈øelves a ble≈ø≈øed death without a holy life.

La≈øtly, Be ≈øtedfa≈øt in adhering to the truth: be not like children carried to and fro with every vaine per≈øwa≈øion; nor like ≈øhips without anchor, to≈ø≈øed up and downe with the winde of every empty doctrine: But be con≈øtant in following the truth, as the Wi≈øemen did the ≈øtarre, untill you come home to Chri≈øt; and as the I≈øraelites did the fiery pillar, untill you come to the heavenly Canaan. Buy the truth (≈øaith Solomon) and ≈øell it not; you can never over-buy it what≈øoever you give for it; you can never ≈øufficiently ≈øell it, if you have all the world in exchange for it. It is ≈øaid of Cae≈øar, Major fuit cura Cae≈øari libellorum qu√†m purpurae; He had greater care of his books then of his royall robes: for ≈øwimming through the waters to e≈øcape his enemies, he carried his books in his hand above the waters, but lo≈øt his robe. What are Cae≈øars bookes to Gods booke, and his learning to Gods truth, more then a glow-worme to the ≈øunne? Bee you therefore more carefull of the Go≈øpel then of any earthly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion: though you bee driven into the deepe waters of affliction, and there lo≈øe all your worldly fulne≈ø≈øe, yet hold fa≈øt the Go≈øpel of Chri≈øt Je≈øus: you ≈øhall finde infinitely more worth and comfort
in the Go≈øpel, then in all the trea≈øure of the world.

It is reported of Alexander the Great, that hee had alwayes Homers Iliads under his pillow, and preferred them above Darius his mo≈øt precious and co≈øtly che≈øt: what are Homers Iliads to Chri≈øts Go≈øpel? or Darius che≈øt to the invaluable trea≈øure which is in Chri≈øt? Have therefore the booke of God ever with you, when you lye downe, when you ri≈øe up, when you walke abroad; have it in your under≈øtandings, to know it; in your imaginations, to thinke and meditate upon it; in your memories, to remember it; in your hearts, to love it, to rejoice and delight your ≈øelves in it; to ≈øolace, refre≈øh, and comfort your ≈øoules with it; in your tongues, to ≈øpeake of it, to edifie and ≈øtrengthen one another by it; give it preheminence above the chiefe≈øt wordly ≈øub≈øtance. div.head: CHAP. I. Shewing the tran≈øcendencie of Chri≈øts fulne≈ø≈øe above all created fulne≈ø≈øe, and opening the ≈øcope of the words.
div.p:
OF all Fulne≈ø≈øe, Divine and Heavenly fulne≈ø≈øe is the choyce≈øt: The nearer any creature commeth unto God, and the more it doth participate of the fulne≈ø≈øe of God; the greater is the perfection,
the more excellent is the fulne≈ø≈øe thereof. There is a fulne≈ø≈øe of light in the Sunne, a fulne≈ø≈øe of waters in the ≈øea, a fulne≈ø≈øe of ≈øtrength in the rockes, a fulne≈ø≈øe of riches in the earth.P≈øa. 104.24. The earth (≈øaith the P≈øalmi≈øt) is full of thy riches, ≈øo is the great and wide ≈øea, wherein are things creeping innumerable, both ≈ømall and great bea≈øts: Yet of all this fulne≈ø≈øe, in compari≈øon of their fulne≈ø≈øe who are filled with the fulne≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt, may wee ≈øay, as Gideon ≈øometime ≈øaid of the vintage of Abiezer, Iudg. 8.2. The gleanings of Ephraim are better then the vintage of Abiezer; ≈øo the gleaning, the ≈ømalle≈øt gatherings of the fulne≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt, are better, more excellent, more ≈øatisfactory, more permanent, then the full and greate≈øt vintage of the world: this is a fulne≈ø≈øe making like God, endearing to God, leading to heavenly and ≈øweet communion with God: the lea≈øt of Chri≈øt is better then the greate≈øt abundance of the earth: There is a fulne≈ø≈øe of wi≈øedome and puritie, a fulne≈ø≈øe of ≈øtrength and ≈øagacity in the Angels: there is a fulne≈ø≈øe of holine≈ø≈øe and righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe in the Lords faithfull ≈øervants; yet is their fulne≈ø≈øe in re≈øpect of Chri≈øts fulne≈ø≈øe, as no fulne≈ø≈øe; as the fulne≈ø≈øe
of the Starre is as no fulne≈øs in re≈øpect of the fulne≈ø≈øe of the Sunne; and the fulne≈ø≈øe of the ve≈ø≈øell as no fulne≈ø≈øe in compari≈øon of the fulne≈ø≈øe of the fountaine: their fulne≈ø≈øe is a derivative, a borrowed fulne≈ø≈øe; it is in them by participation, as the Moone hath her light from the Sunne, rivers their waters from the fountaine, and the eye her ≈øight from the ≈øoule; but it is in Chri≈øt originally, naturally, and of him≈øelfe: their fulne≈ø≈øe is in them by mea≈øure, according to the gift of God; in Chri≈øt it isEph. 4.7. Job. 4.33. Ioh. 1.16. infinite and above mea≈øure. The Moone is full of light, but the Sunne is more full: the Rivers be full of waters, but the Sea is more full; their fulne≈ø≈øe is not communicable to others, they cannot derive their graces to others; but Chri≈øt as a head and fountaine, imparts his fulne≈ø≈øe to others; and therefore the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith here of him, In him dwelleth the fulne≈ø≈øe of the God-head bodily, and yee are complete in him who is head of all Principality and power.

The Apo≈øtle having dehorted and di≈ø≈øwaded from hearkning to, receiving,Chri≈øts fulne≈øs the ground of the Apo≈øtles dehortation from humane doctrine. and embracing the doctrines, traditions, devices and inventions of men, as from emptie Lamps, wherein is no light to di≈øcover ≈øin,
to reveale God in Chri≈øt, to make man wi≈øe unto ≈øalvation; as from woodden ≈øwords fairly guilt and flouri≈øht over, but having no edge, no power to penetrate the heart, to hew downe ≈øinne, to ca≈øt downe the holds of ungodline≈ø≈øe; as from broken Ci≈øternes, wherein is no pure and living water to refre≈øh the ≈øoule, to ≈øatisfie the thir≈øt thereof; as from Chaffe, wherein is no nouri≈øhment to ≈øtrengthen the inward man; and as from fal≈øe Phy≈øicke, wherein is no vertue to heale the breaches of the ≈øoule, and to cure the wounds of the Con≈øcience: Having di≈ø≈øwaded from this by an argument drawne from the vanitie, emptine≈ø≈øe, idlene≈ø≈øe, unprofitablene≈ø≈øe, and deceitfulne≈ø≈øe of ≈øuch doctrines and ob≈øervations, hee here per≈øwades by another argument drawne from the perfection and fulne≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt: In Chri≈øt is the height of all perfection, ≈øuch perfection that no more can bee added to him; in him meets the fulne≈ø≈øe of all perfections, as of beames in one Sunne, and lines in one Center, and rivers in one Ocean. What≈øoever fulne≈ø≈øe or perfection can bee mentioned, de≈øired, imagined, it is to bee found in him. It is ab≈øurd to runne to a rotten Ci≈øterne for
water, having by us a full and living fountaine; to goe to a glow-worme for light, having the Sunne to guide us. It is a great folly to have recour≈øe to humane traditions, Philo≈øophicall doctrines, vaine and empty ceremonies, having Chri≈øt in whom dwelleth the fulne≈ø≈øe of the God-head bodily, and in whom we are complete.

In the words wee have a double plenitude or fulne≈ø≈øe; The fir≈øt of Chri≈øt, A double Fulne≈ø≈øe. ver≈ø. 9. The ≈øecond of his members, ver≈ø. 10. The fir≈øt is originall, ab≈øolute, independent: the ≈øecond, communicated, derivative, and borrowed. The fir≈øt is the fountaine, the ≈øecond the ≈øtreame: the fir≈øt the root, the ≈øecond the branch: the fir≈øt is of the head, the ≈øecond is of the members: the fir≈øt is like the fulne≈ø≈øe of the Sunne, the ≈øecond is like the fulne≈ø≈øe of the Starres: the fir≈øt like the fulne≈ø≈øe of a King, the ≈øecond like the fulne≈ø≈øe of a Subject: the former like the fulne≈ø≈øe of the Lord and Ma≈øter of the hou≈øe, the later like the fulne≈ø≈øe of a Servant in the hou≈øe: For in Chri≈øt dwelleth all the fulne≈ø≈øe of the God-head bodily, and wee are complete in him who is head of all principality and power.

and fulne≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt; For in him dwelleth the fulne≈ø≈øe of the God-head bodily. In the words wee have, 1. Terminus connexionis. Fir≈øt a terme or note of coherence, For; which is a particle redditive, rendring the rea≈øon of the foregoing ≈øentence, Beware le≈øt any man ≈øpoyle you through Philo≈øophy and vaine deceit. Be not a ≈øcholler in their ≈øchoole, under≈øtand not, beleeve not, adore not after their doctrines, there is no need of having recour≈øe to them: you have all in Chri≈øt; For in him is the fulne≈ø≈øe of the God head; all fulne≈ø≈øe appertaining to life and happine≈ø≈øe is to bee found in Chri≈øt Je≈øus.2. Subjectum. Secondly, here is a ≈øubject, in him; in Chri≈øt in his per≈øon as he is the Sonne of God by eternall generation, as he is God and Man in one per≈øon, as hee is Mediatour, a middle per≈øon between God and Man by divine ordination, by his office of mediation. In Chri≈øt is ≈øuch perfection that there needs no addition.3. Actus. Thirdly, here is the act, dwelleth; an act of duration, Chri≈øts humane nature and his God-head are never ≈øeparated. Fourthly,4. Tantum. here is the matter which is in Chri≈øt, and that is a fulne≈ø≈øe, a perfection, the highe≈øt perfection, the greate≈øt fulne≈ø≈øe: the fulne≈ø≈øe of any thing is the excellencie of the
thing; fulne≈ø≈øe of corne in the eare, fulne≈ø≈øe of branches and fruit on the tree, fulne≈ø≈øe of children in the hou≈øe, as of arrowes in a quiver, fulne≈ø≈øe of light in the Sunne, fulne≈ø≈øe of pretious ≈øub≈øtance in a pearle is the excellencie of the eare, the tree, the hou≈øe, the Sunne, the pearle; divine and incomprehen≈øible fulne≈ø≈øe is the excellencie of Chri≈øt Je≈øus above others. Such is Chri≈øts fulne≈ø≈øe, that in compari≈øon thereof, the fulne≈ø≈øe of all creatures is but emptine≈ø≈øe. 5.5. Quale. Here is the qualitie or condition of Chri≈øts fulne≈ø≈øe, The fulne≈ø≈øe of the God-head; a fulne≈ø≈øe communicable to no creature. In Saints and Angels there is a finite fulne≈øs of divine qualities, in Chri≈øt there is the infinite fulne≈øs of the divine e≈øsence, a fulne≈øse by whichHeb. 1.4. hee hath obtained a more excellent name then the Angels. Modus. here is the manner how this fulne≈øs dwelleth in Chri≈øt, Bodily; not ≈øeemingly, but really, truly, and in deed; not figuratively, and in ≈øhadow, as hee dwelt in the Temple, but completely; not by power and efficacie, as hee dwelleth in all

But let not us under-value Chri≈øt for this, but rather admire the fulne≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt, in putting ≈øuch power into the plaine preaching of his Word, and ≈øuch efficacie into the labours of his de≈øpi≈øed Me≈ø≈øengers, as thereby to convince and convert the hearts, and rai≈øe the ≈øoules of men; and by weake things, poore things, and things which are not, to confound the things that are: The weakne≈ø≈øe of the in≈øtrument commends the power of the ≈øupreme agent; the more
wee looke upon the emptine≈ø≈øe of the in≈øtruments which Chri≈øt u≈øeth, the more cau≈øe we ≈øhall have to admire the fulne≈ø≈øe which he communicateth.

Foure things there are among many,Foure things in Chri≈øt to be highly prized. in Chri≈øt, which wee ≈øhould very highly prize: Fir≈øt, the knowledge of Chri≈øt. The wi≈øedome of Solomon was ≈øo great, that the Queene of the South accounted his men happy,1. Knowledge of Chri≈øt. that they might daily ≈øtand before him to heare his wi≈øedome: As Chri≈øt is greater then Solomon, ≈øo is their happine≈ø≈øe greater that may ≈øt ‚Ä¢ nd before him and heare his wi≈øedome. It is Chri≈øt that puts a fulne≈ø≈øe into our knowledge, as the ≈øhining of the Sunne in the aire, puts a fulne≈ø≈øe of light into the eye; therefore Paul made Chri≈øt crucified the center and circumference of his knowledge, determining to know1 Cor. 2.2. nothing among them, but Chri≈øt crucified: this hee made theEphe≈ø. 3. bredth and length, depth and height of his knowledge: this was the full latitude of his knowledge, to know Chri≈øt; and this isPhil. 3.8. excellent knowledge, for the in≈øtrument, authour, matter, ≈øubject, fruits and effects of it; ≈øaving knowledge, Joh. 17.3. Secondly, wee ≈øhould
highly prize the love of CHRIST JESUS;2. Love of Chri≈øt. it is better then Cant. 1.3. wine; nothing ≈øo ≈øolaceth, reviveth, and cheri≈øheth the ≈øoule, nothing is ≈øweet, nothing is ≈øatisfactory without it. It could not2 Sam. 14.32. content Ab≈øolon that he was recalled from his exilement, and had his dwelling at Ieru≈øalem, unle≈ø≈øe hee might al≈øo ≈øee the Kings face: the pre≈øence of all things is as nothing, unle≈ø≈øe man ≈øee the Kings face, feele the love of Chri≈øt; this is the life of a good mans life, as Solomon ≈øaith of the light of the KingsPro. 16.15. countenance, In the light of the Kings countenance is life, and his favour is as a cloud of the latter raine. Chri≈øts love is life quickning, a cloud watering and abundantly refre≈øhing the ≈øoules of all that enjoy him: Therefore e≈øteeme the love of Chri≈øt above the love of the creature, as men e≈øteeme the love of the King above the love of the begger.

Thirdly, wee ≈øhould highly value the communion and mini≈øtration of Chri≈øt:3. The communication and mini≈øtration of Chri≈øt. The Sunne filleth the aire with light, the head filleth the body with ≈øen≈øe and motion, the Schoole filleth the braine with Art and Learning, the golden Mine filleth
the ≈øtore-hou≈øe with trea≈øure, the ≈øea≈øt filleth the hungry with meat, and the clouds fill the earth with fruit; & all the≈øe are e≈øteemed for their mini≈øtration and filling: But Chri≈øt hath a more excellent mini≈øtration, hee filleth with better light then the Sun, with better Art & Learning then the Schoole, with better ≈øen≈øe & motion then the head, with better meat then the fea≈øt, with better fruit then the cloud: He filleth the hungry with Luke 1.53. good things, with ≈øpiritual and heavenly good things, ≈øaving knowledge, lively faith, fervent love, Chri≈øtian patience, true humility and meekne≈øs, even with the whole trea≈øury of all ≈øpirituall good things, even ≈øuch good things as1 Cor. 2.9. carnall eye hath not ≈øeene, uncircumci≈øed eare hath not heard, nor have entred into the unregenerate heart of man: the≈øe doth Chri≈øt reveale and communicate by his Spirit, and in this mini≈øtration ≈øtands the happine≈ø≈øe, glory, and comfort of man; Chri≈øt becomming their fulne≈ø≈øe, andEphe≈ø. 1.23. filling all in all, by being the fulne≈ø≈øe of their knowledge, of their faith, of their love, of their peace, of their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; without whom all knowledge, faith, love, and what≈øoever el≈øe, is but an empty thing.
Give then preheminence to Chri≈øts mini≈øtration, above the mini≈øtration of the creature; as to the mini≈øtration of corne above chaffe, of gold above dro≈ø≈øe. Oh prize the gift of Chri≈øt above all the gifts of the world.

4. The ≈øweet & ble≈ø≈øed pre≈øence of Chri≈øt.Fourthly, wee ≈øhould highly prize the ble≈ø≈øed, ≈øweet and gracious pre≈øence of Chri≈øt; as a good ≈øubject doth the pre≈øence of his King in his hou≈øe, above all other friends; as a wife the pre≈øence of her hu≈øband above all neighbours. Wee mu≈øt not ≈øo e≈øteeme the pre≈øence of riches, honours, friends, or any other endowments, as wee doe the pre≈øence of Chri≈øt. This Chri≈øt hath promi≈øed to his children, as their ≈øtaffe and ≈øtay, crowne and glory, prerogative and comfort:Mat. 28.20. I≈øa. 43.2. Lo (≈øaith hee) I am with you to the end of the world; with you as a King among his people, as a Father among his children, as a Shepheard with his flocke, as a Teacher among his Schollers. This was ≈øhadowed by the fierie Pillar that was pre≈øent with I≈ørael as a guide, which they followed in their ≈øeverall campings, as a defence between the Campes of I≈ørael and the Egyptians: ≈øo is Chri≈øt pre≈øent with us as a
guide to direct us in our journies, as a protector to defend us from all our enemies. The Pillar was a cloud by day, and a fire by night to I≈ørael: ≈øo is Chri≈øt a cooling refre≈øhment to his children in the ≈øcorching day of trouble, and a comfortable Lampe of light to direct them in the night of this world. In the fire and in the cloud God was ≈øeene by I≈ørael: in Chri≈øt God is ≈øeene and knowne as a Father of mercies by his children; and this pre≈øence of Chri≈øt with us ≈øhould wee highly e≈øteeme, as the Traveller doth the pre≈øence of the Sunne: This encourageth, comforteth, ≈øtrengtheneth, ≈øati≈øfieth, and ≈øhould accordingly bee highly prized. And thus let us value, prize, and preferre Chri≈øt according to his fulne≈ø≈øe, that Chri≈øt may value us as Schollers of his Schoole, as Subjects of his Kingdome, as Lovers of his Truth, as Members of his Body, and daily more and more fill us with his divine and heavenly fulne≈ø≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Per≈øwading to come unto, and get intere≈øt in Chri≈øt.

AS all divine and heavenly fulne≈ø≈øe is in Chri≈øt, ≈øo it ≈øhould move and per≈øwade all men to come to Chri≈øt, to get intere≈øt in Chri≈øt, to ≈øeeke for all fulne≈ø≈øe in him. As Hagar went to the full Well, and filled her emptie Bottle; ≈øo let us come to Chri≈øt, the true and living fountaine, and fill our empty ≈øoules with the fulne≈ø≈øe of his grace. Fulne≈ø≈øe is the common de≈øire of all per≈øons; the ambitious de≈øires fulne≈ø≈øe of honours, the covetous fulne≈ø≈øe of riches, the voluptuous fulne≈ø≈øe of plea≈øures: they are very greedy, and can never have I≈øa. 56.10. enough of this fulne≈ø≈øe. Much more ≈øhould Chri≈øtians de≈øire the fulne≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt, the onely true and de≈øirable fulne≈ø≈øe. As Davids Worthies in the day of Davids thir≈øt, brake through the Phili≈øtian Army, and drew water out of the well at Bethel: ≈øo let us in the day of our Chri≈øt, in the time of our want, breake through all impediments, all armies of trouble and oppo≈øition rai≈øed again≈øt us,
and come to Chri≈øt, the Well, whence come the waters of ≈øalvation. To this Chri≈øt him≈øelf invites us,Mat. 11.28. Come unto mee; Come unto me as the ≈øick unto the Phy≈øician to heale you of all your ≈øinfull maladies: Come unto me as the Traveller to the Sunne, to fill you with all divine and heavenly light, to guide you in all your goings: Come unto mee as the thir≈øty to the living fountaine, to ≈øupply all your wants, to fill all your de≈øires: Come unto me as the Sheepe to the Shepheard, to lead you be≈øide the ≈øtill waters, and to feed you in the greene pa≈øtures: Come unto mee as the Chicken to the Hen, to hide you under the wings of my protection: Come unto me as the poore unto the rich, as the Buyer to the Merchants ≈øhop, and buy of mee,Non precio ≈øed prece. not for price, but by prayer,Rev. 3.18 gold tried in the fire, that thou maye≈øt be rich; and white rayment, that thou maye≈øt bee cloathed; and eye-≈øalve, that thou maye≈øt ≈øee: And thus runnes the charge of the Lord by the Prophet,I≈øa. 45.22. Look unto mee, and bee yee ≈øaved, all yee ends of the earth: Looke unto mee with the eyes of faith, beleeving in mee and my promi≈øes; with the eyes of godly ≈øorrow,
mourning for your ≈øinnes and offences; with the eyes of love, embracing me as the husband of your ≈øoules; with the eyes of obedience, fearing and obeying mee above all commanders. Thus looke unto mee, and bee yee ≈øaved; ≈øaved from ≈øinne, that it ≈øway not over you; ≈øaved from Satan, that hee rule not within you; ≈øaved from affliction, that it ≈øhall not ≈øwallow you; and ≈øaved from the Law, that it ≈øhall not condemne you. Chri≈øt mini≈øters all ≈øalvation to them that by a lively faith come unto him: this is the end and fruit of Chri≈øts comming by his Word and Spirit to the ≈øoules of men: My Cant. 2.10. beloved (≈øaith the Spou≈øe) ≈øpoke unto mee, outwardly by his Word and Mini≈øters, and inwardly by his Spirit, Ari≈øe up, my Love, my faire one, and come away: Ri≈øe up from the death of ≈øinne, as ≈øometime the dead ro≈øe up from the grave; from the di≈øea≈øe of ≈øinne, ignorance, unbeliefe, impenitencie, as the ≈øicke ari≈øe from their di≈øea≈øe, and returne to health; from the ≈øleep and ≈ølumber, reigne and rule of ≈øinne, as Peter aro≈øe from his ≈øleepe, his fetters, the two Souldiers, and came forth of Herods pri≈øon; from communion and fellow≈øhip
with corrupt and carnall men, as Lazarus ro≈øe out of his grave from the fellow≈øhip of the dead: Ri≈øe up and come away from the world, carnall acquaintance, and fle≈øhly delights, as the Bride comes awayP≈øal. 45.10. from her owne people, and her fathers hou≈øe, unto the Bride-groome; as ≈øometime Abraham Gen. 12.1. came away from his owne countrey, and from his kindred, and from his fathers hou≈øe, unto a land which the Lord ≈øhewed him: Ari≈øe and come away from all ≈øinfull plea≈øures, as Sam≈øon aro≈øe from Delilahs lap, bur≈øt his withs a≈øunder, and came away from her: Ri≈øe up and come away from all corrupt and carnall doctrine, as the prodigall aro≈øe from the huskes and the ≈øwine, and came to his fathers hou≈øe, to eate his fathers bread: Ri≈øe up and come away even from thy ≈øelfe, by ≈øelfe-deniall, and putting off thy old man, as Lazarus ro≈øe up, put away his grave-clothes, and left them behinde him: Thus ri≈øe up and come away to Chri≈øt. That man alone comes to Chri≈øt Je≈øus, who ri≈øeth up from the world, him≈øelfe, and his own corrupt affections: And unto him let us come as the lame man came to Bethe≈øda, that we may be healed;

Three things per≈øwading to come to Chri≈øt.And the more effectually to move and per≈øwade you to come to Chri≈øt, fa≈øten your hearts and thoughts ≈øeriou≈øly upon the≈øe three things:

1. Nece≈ø≈øitie of Chri≈øt.Mans nece≈ø≈øity of Chri≈øt, Mans mi≈øery without Chri≈øt: Man is ≈øpiritually dead, and none but Chri≈øt can rai≈øe him. The manner of comming to Chri≈øt. 1. SpeedilyTo him let us come, fir≈øt, ≈øpeedily, without all delay, as Eagles to the carca≈ø≈øe. Con≈øideration of Satans Siege. div.head: CHAP. IX. Teaching how to make u≈øe of Chri≈øt.
div.p:
IS all divine and heavenly fulne≈ø≈øe in Chri≈øt? is it all placed there? Then wee mu≈øt make u≈øe of Chri≈øt, as the child of full brea≈øts, as the thir≈øty of a full ve≈ø≈øell. Chri≈øts fulne≈ø≈øe is nothing to him that makes not u≈øe of Chri≈øt: There is a price (≈øaith Solomon) in the hand of a foole, but hee hath no heart to u≈øe it: There is a tran≈øcendent fulne≈ø≈øe in Chri≈øt, and hee is the choyce≈øt of all prices, and is even put into the hands of men; but many have no heart to make u≈øe of him, and therefore hee doth not profit them. What is the fulne≈ø≈øe of the Sunne to the blinde that doth not ≈øee by it? the fulne≈ø≈øe of the fountaine to him that doth not drinke of it? the fulne≈ø≈øe of the fea≈øt to him that doth not feed upon it? and what is the fulne≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt to him that makes no u≈øe of Chri≈øt? What is a man the better for a locke, if hee hath not a key to u≈øe it
withall? It is not a trade, but a trade well followed; it is not land, but land well tilled that maintaines men, that makes men rich: It is not Chri≈øt, but Chri≈øt well u≈øed that maintaines the ≈øoule, that makes the ≈øoule rich.Eccle≈ø. 5.18, 19. Behold (≈øaith Solomon) that which I have ≈øeene, it is good and comely for one to eate and drinke, and to enjoy the good of all his labour that hee taketh under the Sunne, all the dayes of his life which God giveth him, for it is his portion. Every man al≈øo to whom God hath given riches and wealth, and hath given him power to eate thereof, and to take his portion, and to rejoyce in his labour, this is the gift of God. Chri≈øt is a rarer portion then all wealth, then all meat and drinke; it is a rarer gift of God to make u≈øe of Chri≈øt, and to enjoy the good of Chri≈øt, all the dayes of his life: this is the portion of a Chri≈øtian, of a gracious and ≈øanctified ≈øoule indeed. As therefore the healthy man makes u≈øe of his meat, and is ≈øtrengthened; the ≈øick man makes u≈øe of his phy≈øicke, and is healed; the Souldier maketh u≈øe of his weapon, and overcommeth; the Merchant maketh u≈øe of his trade, and growes rich by it: Thus let us make u≈øe of Chri≈øt
that our ≈øoules may bee healed, ≈øtrengthened, made victorious, and ≈øpiritually enriched. Some men live by their wits, ≈øome by their lands, and ≈øome by their trades: the Chri≈øtian lives by his Chri≈øt. Of Chri≈øt therefore let us make u≈øe in our Under≈øtandings, to fill us with the knowledge of Gods will in all wi≈øedome, to receive all our direction from him, as the traveller maketh u≈øe of the Sunne to guide him. Of him let us make u≈øe in our Meditations, thinke upon him as the Bride in her thoughts maketh u≈øe of the Bride-groome; let the thought of Chri≈øt bee frequent and pretious, and the meditation of Chri≈øtP≈ø. 104.34. ≈øweet unto us. Of him let us make u≈øe by our Faith, depending upon him as the hou≈øe upon the rocke, ca≈øting our ≈øelves, our care and burthen upon him; as the childe upon the parent, hiding our ≈øelves under the ≈øhadow of his wings; as the chicken under the wings of the hen, re≈øting upon him for a ≈øupply in all our wants, for a deliverance in all di≈øtre≈ø≈øes, making him in ≈øtead of all in the ab≈øence of all helpers, deriving and drawing more and more from his fulne≈ø≈øe, as the thir≈øty draw waters out of the Well by
the bucket, and as the branches draw nouri≈øhment from the roots. Of him let us make u≈øe by our Love, loving him as the Father begetting, the Ran≈øomer redeeming, the Phy≈øician healing, the Husband marrying, and Trea≈øure enriching our ≈øoules. Of him let us make u≈øe in our Ioy, rejoycing in him as the wi≈øe men in the Starre, with an Mat. 2.10. exceeding great joy. Of him let us make u≈øe in our peace and pro≈øperity, looking on him as the authour of all our happine≈ø≈øe, as the Sunne that puts a fulne≈ø≈øe into all the lights of our comforts, as the Sunne puts a fulne≈ø≈øe into the ≈øtarres: without Chri≈øt all is empty, as a withered branch without the root: all is bitter as the waters of Marah without the tree. Of him let us make u≈øe in our hearing, preaching, prayer, conference; him let us heare, him let us learne, of him let us ≈øpeake, him let us ≈øet forth.Aridus e≈øt omnis animae cibus, fi non oleo i≈øto in≈øunditur: in≈øipidus e≈øt ≈øi non hoc ≈øale conditur: ≈øi ≈øcribas, non ≈øapit mihi, ni≈øi legero ibi Ie≈øum: ≈øi di≈øputes, aut conf ‚Ä¢
ras, non ≈øapit mihi, n ‚Ä¢ ≈øi ≈øonuerit ibi Je≈øus.
Bernard ≈øaith, All the food of the ≈øoule is dry, if it bee not put into this oyle; it is un≈øavory if it bee not ≈øea≈øoned with this ≈øalt: if thou write≈øt, it doth not reli≈øh with mee, unle≈ø≈øe I read JESUS there: if thou doe≈øt di≈øpute or conferre, it doth not reli≈øh wel with me, unle≈ø≈øe JESUS found there: if we make
not u≈øe of Chri≈øt Je≈øus, our u≈øe of Gods ordinance is fruitle≈ø≈øe. Of Chri≈øt let us make u≈øe in our di≈øtre≈ø≈øes, as Noah made u≈øe of the Arke in the deluge, to ≈øupport us; as the Gibeonites made u≈øe of Jo≈øua in the ≈øiege, to helpe us, to deliver us; as Hagar made u≈øe of the Well when her bottle was empty, to fill us. O let not Chri≈øt bee to us as Iethers ≈øword to him which hee drew not, u≈øed not; as wealth to many to whom God gives not power to eate, as a cordiall to him that doth not receive it, or a garment to him that doth not put it on; but let us every way make u≈øe of Chri≈øt: make u≈øe of his wi≈øedome to guide us, of his power to uphold us, of his dominion to awe us, of his maje≈øty to humble us, of his puritie to make us vile in our owne eyes, to ≈øhame us for our uncleanne≈ø≈øe, to worke us to holine≈ø≈øe; of his ju≈øtice to drive us from ≈øinne, of his righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe to cloath us and cover our ≈øinnes, of his mercie to pardon us, of his love to comfort us, of his pre≈øence to encourage us, of his fulne≈ø≈øe to ≈øatisfie us, of his Word to feed us, of his Sacraments to confirme us, of his death to mortifie our lu≈øts, of his re≈øurrection to quicken
our ≈øoules, of his ≈øufferings to ≈øuffer with patience, of his interce≈ø≈øion to ≈øettle us in the a≈ø≈øurance of the pardon of our ≈øinnes, and e≈øtabli≈øhment of the love of God on our ≈øoules; of his commandements as of a ≈øpurre to quicken us in his ≈øervice, and as of a bridle to re≈øtraine us from what is forbidden; of his promi≈øes as of a rocke to ≈øu≈øtaine us, as of a load-≈øtone to draw us, as of a light in darkne≈ø≈øe to comfort us, and as of a ≈øpring in the day of drought to refre≈øh and fill us. Excellent is the u≈øe of Chri≈øt Je≈øus to the ≈øoules of all true Chri≈øtians; it extirpates all cares, di≈øpelleth all feares, evacuates the minde of di≈øtracting thoughts and di≈øturbing pa≈ø≈øions, ≈øweetens all e≈øtates, mitigates all ≈øorrowes, facilitateth all burdens, and exhilerates the whole man. Very great is the ≈øoules happine≈ø≈øe which makes a true, full, and con≈øtant u≈øe of Chri≈øt Je≈øus.

div.head: CHAP. X. Per≈øwading to full and con≈øtant acquie≈øcence in Chri≈øt.
div.p:
AS there is all fulne≈ø≈øe in Chri≈øt, ≈øo all Chri≈øtians mu≈øt worke their hearts to a holy, gracious, full and con≈øtant acquie≈øcence in Chri≈øt, to ≈øtay on Chri≈øt, to quiet and content them≈øelves in and with Chri≈øt, never declining from Chri≈øt, never ≈øtepping out, nor going a≈øide from Chri≈øt to any other helper; but as the eye doth quiet it ≈øelfe in the fulne≈øs of the light of the Sun, and looks for no other light; the builder quiets him≈øelfe in the ≈øtrength of the rock, and looks out for no other foundation to build upon: So let us quiet our ≈øelves in Chri≈øt, and looke for no other guide, no other ≈øupporter, no other helper, no other comforter, no other Saviour. As old Iacob ≈øometime ≈øaid of Io≈øeph, It is G ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . 45. ‚Ä¢ 8. enough, Io≈øeph is yet alive, I will goe and ≈øee him: ≈øo let us ≈øay, It is enough, Chri≈øt liveth, Chri≈øt reigneth, Chri≈øt hath fulne≈ø≈øe, wee will goe to him, ≈øtay on him, ≈øatiate and delight our ≈øoules in him: This the Lord requires, Hee I≈ø ‚Ä¢ y 5 ‚Ä¢ .10. that walkes in

As the hou≈øe in the Parable ≈øtayed upon the rocke when the windes did blow, and the waves did beat: thus in the windes and waves of all trouble, let us ≈øtay on Chri≈øt without wavering; to this the Lord gives many ≈øweet encouragements,P≈øal. 37. Ver≈øe 3. Tru≈øt in the Lord with a full, a quiet, a compo≈øed and re≈øolved minde, and doe good, live graciou≈øly, walke holily, keepe clo≈øe to God, ≈øo ≈øhalt thou dwell in the land; thou ≈øhalt not bee di≈ømayed with any feares, nor grow impatient with troubles, nor bee overcome with ≈øorrowes, nor removed from thy ≈øtation, but verily thou ≈øhalt bee fed, thou ≈øhalt enjoy every nece≈ø≈øary good thing with a ≈øettled, quiet & contented minde:Ver≈øe 4. Delight thy ≈øelfe al≈øo in Lord, as a childe in the father, as a wife in the husband, as a rich man in his trea≈øury; delight thy ≈øelfe in the commandement of God as in the light which guides thee, in the promi≈øe of God as in the ≈øtaffe which ≈øu≈øtaines thee, in the favour of God as in the warme≈øt Sunne that ever ≈øhined upon thee, in the attributes of God as in the branches ≈øhadowing, and ≈øtreams
refre≈øhing thee: Thus delight thy ≈øelfe in the Lord, and hee ≈øhall give thee thy hearts de≈øire; he ≈øhall fully an≈øwer all thy holy and gracious de≈øires, when thou ha≈øt thus fully committed thy ≈øelfe unto him, and quieted thy ≈øelfe with him:ver≈øe 5. Commit thy way al≈øo to the Lord, receive all thy direction from him, doe all according to his pre≈øcription, leave the i≈ø≈øue of all to his di≈øpo≈øition, and he ≈øhall bring it to pa≈ø≈øe, give it ≈øuch an i≈ø≈øue as ≈øhall be greatly for thy comfort:ver≈øe 7. Re≈øt in the Lord and wait patiently for him; though thou ≈øuffer many evils, doe not repine, doe not limit nor pre≈øcribe God, doe not ≈øtep a≈øide from God to any forbidden helpes, ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe the tumults of thy heart, and wait as Noah did for the abatement of the waters, and comming of the Dove, quiet thy ≈øelfe in Chri≈øt: looke upon the authoritie of Chri≈øt, to di≈øpen≈øe all as hee plea≈øeth; upon the wi≈øedome of Chri≈øt, to make a way for thy ≈øoule to e≈øcape; upon the power of Chri≈øt, to deliver thee; upon the pre≈øence of Chri≈øt, to mini≈øter encouragement to thee; upon the love of Chri≈øt, to ≈øweeten the bittere≈øt e≈øtate unto thy ≈øoule; upon the faithfulne≈øs
of Chri≈øt, never to for≈øake thee; upon the happines of cleaving clo≈øe to Chri≈øt, thogh all the world oppo≈øe thee; and upon the abundant fulne≈ø≈øe that Chri≈øt is to thy ≈øoule, when all other things are taken from thee, and thou ≈øhalt ≈øolace and ≈øtay thy ≈øelfe upon Chri≈øts fulne≈ø≈øe with a full acquie≈øcence.

From the fulne≈ø≈øe of the Lord JESUS flowes a full fountaine of con≈øolation to the ≈øoules of all beleevers,7. Con≈øolations flowing from Chri≈øts fulne≈ø≈øe. con≈øolation again≈øt all externall wants: He cannot bee poore that hath Chri≈øt, in whom is all fulne≈ø≈øe; when hee is ≈øpoyled of all, hee hath an abiding ≈øub≈øtance. Chri≈øt is the Sunne in whom is all light, the Pearle in whom is all worth, the Tree on whom grows all fruit: The Soule which is e≈øpou≈øed to the heire of all things, hath no cau≈øe to complaine of the want of riches: hee that enjoyes Chri≈øt, and di≈øtracts him≈øelfe about worldly abilities, knowes not his own happine≈ø≈øe; under-values the portion which God hath given him, having a fea≈øt of fat things, a rich jewell, a living ≈øpring, a glorious Sunne at home, ≈øeekes abroad for huskes to feed him, dro≈ø≈øe to enrich him, a glow-worme to warme him,
and ditch and dirty water to quench the thir≈øt that is within him. What is the vintage of Abiezer to the gleanings of Ephraim? the onions and garlicke of Egypt to the grapes of Canaan? Is Pharphar like Jordan? Is the broken ci≈øterne like the fountaine? The fulne≈ø≈øe of the world to the fulne≈øs of Chri≈øt is nothing: hee that hath Chri≈øt, hath the riche≈øt portion, though he have nothing be≈øides him. Here is con≈øolation again≈øt the want of carnall friends, earthly peace, and worldly comforts: though Saul cannot be merry without a Fidler, Ahab without Naboths vineyard, Haman without Mordecays courte≈øie, a man that hath Chri≈øt, hath that which makes him merry without all the≈øe. If Plato could tell the Mu≈øicians that Philo≈øophers knew how to dine and ≈øup without them, much more they who enjoy Chri≈øts fulne≈ø≈øe, know how to ≈øolace them≈øelves in the ab≈øence of earthly comforts. Here is con≈øolation again≈øt all oppo≈øing powers: in Chri≈øt is all fulne≈ø≈øe; hee is a Shepheard able to deliver his flock from the Beare and the Lyon, hee is a wall of fire able to defend his citizens and burne their enemies, hee is a husband
able to re≈øcue his Spou≈øe, and de≈øtroy them that make warre on her, as David re≈øcued his wives, and de≈øtroyed the Amalekites that carried them away captives. Here is con≈øolation again≈øt all ≈øoule infirmities; in Chri≈øt is all fulne≈ø≈øe, fulne≈ø≈øe of mercie to pity and pardon us, fulne≈ø≈øe of power to ≈øtrengthen us, fulne≈ø≈øe of grace to heale us, fulne≈ø≈øe of love to ≈øolace us, fulne≈ø≈øe of peace to quiet us, and the fulnes of all goodnes to perfect us. The Lords ≈øervants ≈øhould not bee ≈øo much dejected with the thought of their owne emptine≈ø≈øe and weakne≈ø≈øe, as revived and cheared with the meditation of Chri≈øts fulne≈ø≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Declaring the in≈øeparable union of Chri≈øt's two natures in one per≈øon.
div.p:
THE third thing in the≈øe words is an act, dwelleth; an act of permanencie and duration, expre≈ø≈øing the in≈øeparable union between the two natures of Chri≈øt in one per≈øon, the divine dwelling in the humane; ManIoh. 6.56. 1 Ioh. 4.16 dwells in Chri≈øt and God by
faith as by an in≈øtrument, by love as by a witne≈ø≈øe of his ≈øocietie and communion with God and Je≈øus Chri≈øt. God and Chri≈øt dwell in men by grace and heavenly effects, regenerating the hearts of men, enlivening the ≈øoules of men, graciou≈øly reigning and ruling within them, plentifully mini≈øtring all ≈øpirituall and heavenly gifts unto them:Rev. 7.15. Hee that ≈øitteth on the throne (≈øaith Saint John) ≈øhall dwell among them; they ≈øhall enjoy his grace and favour here, and his glory hereafter. The God-head dwells in the humane nature of Chri≈øt by per≈øonall and perpetuall union of both natures; and this is the dwelling here ≈øpoken of: Whence wee ≈øee, that

Doctr.
Chri≈øt is God and man in one per≈øon by an in≈øeparable union. The pillar which conducted I≈ørael, was a fire and a cloud, yet both but one Pillar: Chri≈øt the great conductor and guide of Gods I≈ørael, is God and likewi≈øe man, yet in both but one per≈øon, therefore calledI≈øa. 7.14. Immanuel, God with us, or, God made fle≈øh; noting the union of his two natures in one per≈øon, and his office of mediation between God and Man, being the authour of
≈øalvation both temporall and eternall to the ≈øoule and body of man. The Temple was a type of Chri≈øt, ≈øtone without, and gold within: Chri≈øt was fle≈øh without, according to his humane nature; full of re≈øplendent glory, and divine maje≈øtie within, in re≈øpect of his divine nature. In the Temple the glory of God appeared, the Temple was filled with it: in the fle≈øh of Chri≈øt the God-head inhabiteth, mo≈øt gloriou≈øly repleni≈øhing it; The Iohn 1.14. Word (≈øayth Saint John) was made fle≈øh, and dwelt among us, and wee beheld his glory, as the glory of the onely begotten of the Father, full of grace and truth. The Word was made fle≈øh, not by bare and naked inhabitation in the fle≈øh, pre≈øence with the fle≈øh, affection to the fle≈øh, or grace and dignity conferred on the fle≈øh, nor by conver≈øion of the word into fle≈øh, or commixture of the Word with the fle≈øh; but by the a≈ø≈øumption of our fle≈øh into the unitie of his per≈øon, the hypo≈øta≈øis or ≈øub≈øi≈øtence of the Sonne, being made the hypo≈øta≈øis or ≈øub≈øi≈øtence of the fle≈øh a≈ø≈øumed, the fle≈øh ≈øub≈øi≈øting in the per≈øon of the Word. The Apo≈øtle makes mention of the Sonne thus, ≈øpeaking to the Father,Heb. 10.5. Sacrifice and
offering thou would≈øt not, but a body ha≈øt thou fitted me, by incarnation, by uniting it to my per≈øon: and this union is not a union of two per≈øons in one Chri≈øt, but of two natures in one per≈øon; the ≈øub≈øi≈øtence of the word is ≈øo communicated to the fle≈øh, that the Word and fle≈øh are one per≈øon, the naturall properties and operations of both natures remaining di≈øtinct and without confu≈øion: the divine and humane nature are both united, the humane nature is a≈ø≈øumed, the divine nature is the a≈ø≈øument; not the per≈øon but the nature of man, not man but the humanitie is taken by Chri≈øt into the unitie of his per≈øon; otherwi≈øe hee ≈øhould not bee one but two per≈øons, not one but two Chri≈øts: The Scripture therefore calles him Davids Mat. 22.45. Sonne, and Davids Lord, becau≈øe hee is both God and Man in one per≈øon: And this union is without mutation of the divine Per≈øon, without divi≈øion, confu≈øion, or ≈øeparation of the natures; the union is everla≈øtingly permanent. Of this Chri≈øts appearing to the Fathers of old in the ≈øhape of man, were Praeludiums & Symbols: and this was al≈øo typified by the Tabernacle of Mo≈øes in the De≈øert, that being a
type of Chri≈øts a≈ø≈øuming our fle≈øh, and dwelling among≈øt us as in a Tabernacle. The Tabernacle was a te≈øtimony of Gods pre≈øence with his people:Luk 1.18, 78, 79. God by his Sonne made fle≈øh, doth te≈øtifie him≈øelfe to bee graciou≈øly pre≈øent with us. The people came to the Tabernacle to wor≈øhip, invocate and offer their Sacrifice unto God: God will not bee invocated and adored by man, but in and through Chri≈øt manife≈øted in the fle≈øh of man.
And it was nece≈ø≈øary that Chri≈øt ≈øhould be God and Man in one per≈øon:2 Grounds hereof.

In regard of the exaltation of the humane nature of Chri≈øt above all creatures, all Men and Angels:1. Chri≈øts exaltation. Saints and Angels are one with God and Chri≈øt by gracious qualities, con≈øent of will and opinion, and my≈øticall conjunction; the humane nature of Chri≈øt is one with his divine per≈øon by a more tran≈øcendent, eminent, and immediate conjunction, being a≈ø≈øumed into the unity of his per≈øon. Io≈øeph was exalted above his brethren, above all the Nobles in the Court of Pharaoh: Chri≈øt, even according to the fle≈øh, is exalted above all men, yea, above all the Angels, the choyce≈øt Nobles, of him
that is the King of kings. From this per≈øonall union, is derived an incomprehen≈øible communication of all divine and heavenly gifts to the humane nature of Chri≈øt, an unction above P≈ø. 45 7. all his fellowes; like that of Io≈øeph to Benjamin, five times as good, many degrees more excellent then that which is be≈øtowed on his brethren, whether Angels or Men, the Spirit being given unto himIoh. 3.34 above mea≈øure, having all heavenly fulne≈ø≈øe, like the fulne≈ø≈øe of light in the Sunne, or waters in the Sea. From this union the humane nature obtaines the honour of adoration; yet not of the fle≈øh as fle≈øh, but of the God-head in the fle≈øh, the God-head and the manhood making but one per≈øon in the Sonne; and hee is ≈øaid to bee ≈øet downe at the right hand of God, being made ≈øo Heb. 1.4. much better then the Angels as hee hath by inheritance obtained a more excellent name then they; the Angels being ≈øervants, Chri≈øt a Sonne, both by eternall generation, and hypo≈øtaticall union.

2. Mans ≈øalvation.In regard of mans ≈øalvation. Such was mans nece≈ø≈øitie of Chri≈øts incarnation, of his a≈ø≈øuming mans fle≈øh into the unity of his per≈øon, that hee could not bee ≈øaved
but by ≈øuch a Redeemer as was both God and Man in one per≈øon. Fir≈øt, the Maje≈øty of God, the poverty and indigencie of man, the greatne≈ø≈øe of the evill to bee removed, and the greatne≈ø≈øe of the good to bee re≈øtored, required that mans Redeemer ≈øhould bee God: Such is the Maje≈øty of God, that none could interpo≈øe him≈øelfe, but hee that is one with the Father; the Angels could not, they them≈øelves have need of a mediator ofCol. 1.16, 17. union and confirmation; they them≈øelves compared with God, are not Job 15.15. pure in his ≈øight, and therefore theyI≈øa. 6.2. cover their faces: how much le≈ø≈øe can man doe it, when not one of them isRev. 3.10. righteous: The evill to be taken away, ≈øinne and the con≈øequents of ≈øinne, the wrath of God, the power of Satan, death temporall and eternall, are a di≈øea≈øe of that difficultie, that none can cure it, a fire of that heat that none can endure it, a burthen of that weight that none can ≈øtand under it, but hee that is omnipotent: for by who≈øe pa≈ø≈øion can the offence of an infinite Maje≈øtie bee expiated, but by his who is al≈øo infinite? By who≈øe interce≈ø≈øion can the wrath of God be appea≈øed, but by his who is the be≈øt
beloved Son of God? By who≈øe ≈øtrength can Satan, with all the powers of darkne≈ø≈øe, bee vanqui≈øh ‚Ä¢ d, but by his who is ≈øtronger then all the Divels? Who can overcome death, but hee that hath the power of death? The good things to bee re≈øtored, are, perfect righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, adoption, the image of God, the gifts of the Spirit, life eternall, and the like: Now who can make man righteous, but hee that is Righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe it ≈øelfe? Who can make men the ≈øonnes of God by grace, but hee that is the Sonne of God by nature? Who can re≈øtore us to the image of God, but hee that is the invi≈øible image of God? Who can give us the Spirit, but hee from whom the Spirit of God proceedeth? And who can give man eternall life, but hee that is life it ≈øelfe? And thus it behoved mans redeemer to be God.

Secondly, the Ju≈øtice of God (which as it leaveth not ≈øinne unpuni≈øhed, ≈øo it puni≈øheth it not but in that nature which hath ≈øinned) required that hee ≈øhould bee man: And thus hee that knew 2 Cor. 5.21. no ≈øinne, was made ≈øinne for us, that wee might bee made the righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe of God in him. And hee mu≈øt bee God and Man in one per≈øon, that
hee might bee a middle man betweene God and Man, and doe the thi ‚Ä¢ gs which were to bee performed withHeb. 5.1. God, and al≈øo with men. And thus there was a nece≈ø≈øitie that the fulne≈ø≈øe of the Godhead ≈øhould dwell in the humane nature of Chri≈øt, and that hee ≈øhould bee God and man in one per≈øon.

Doth Chri≈øt dwell in mans fle≈øh? U≈øe. Hath hee a≈ø≈øumed mans nature into the unity of his per≈øon?The honor and exaltation of mans nature. then behold the honour of man, how wondrou≈øly Chri≈øt hath exalted the nature of man: Man that by his ≈øinne hath made him≈øelfe extremely ba≈øe and ignominious, is exceedingly honoured by Chri≈øt Je≈øus, even above all the re≈øidue of the creatures: for hee tooke not on him the Heb. 2.16. nature of Angels, but the ≈øeed of Abraham. Hee often u≈øed the Angels as his mini≈øters and in≈øtruments, but tooke them not into the unity of his per≈øon: they have indeed a neere and ≈øweet communion with him, but the nature of man alone hath the prerogative and glory of being one with Chri≈øt per≈øonally. Ambro≈øe ≈øaith,Honorem hunc & digni ‚Ä¢ atem humanae naturae Deus, Dei filius contribuit ut Deus & homo una per≈øona e≈ø≈øet. God, the Sonne of God hath given this honour and dignitie to the humane nature, that God and man ≈øhould bee one per≈øon.
Great is the honour that comes to man by Chri≈øts incarnation; it is onely the Lord Je≈øus that makes man honourable and glorious: the Sunne is the glory of the world, the head is the glory of the body, the crowne is the glory of the King, the flower is the glory of the garden,Prov. 17 6. Childrens children (≈øaith Solomon) are the crowne of old men, and the glory of children are their fathers: but when all is done, the glory of a Chri≈øtian is Chri≈øt Je≈øus; hee that commeth neere≈øt unto Chri≈øt, and is mo≈øt entirely united to him, is of all per≈øons the mo≈øt honourable and glorious. The≈øe are a 1 Pet. 2.9. royall Prie≈øthood, a cho≈øen generation, a peculiar people, called out of darkne≈ø≈øe into a marvelous light. Women ≈øuppo≈øe it a great glory to bee taken into wedlocke by rich men and Nobles, Men repute it a high honour to be received into the favour and fellow≈øhip of Princes, Servants have high thoughts of their being made companions of their Lords and Ma≈øters; but true glory, full & abiding glory commeth unto man by his being received of Chri≈øt, by his having union & communion with Chri≈øt: hee alone is truly honourable and everla≈øtingly
noble, that hath Chri≈øt graciou≈øly dwelling in him; he hath the honour of a Iohn 1.12. Sonne of God by regeneration and adoption, the honour of aIohn 15.15. friend of God for Gods familiar and full imparting of his mind and ≈øecrets to him, the honour of a Rom. 8.37. Conquerour for the victory which Chri≈øt gives him over the Divell, the world, and his owne corruption; the honour of a Ephe≈ø. 5.30. Spou≈øe for Chri≈øts ≈øpirituall wedlock with him, the honour of an Rom. 8.17. heire for his free participation of all the good things of his heavenly Father, and the honour of a Rev. 1.6. King for the ≈øpirituall dominion which hee hath over him≈øelfe and the world. Were man ≈øen≈øible of the honour that comes by the participation of Chri≈øt Je≈øus, hee would never ≈øo ≈øtrive for worldly honours, nor entertaine ≈øuch di≈øhonourable thoughts of the wayes of Chri≈øt and his ≈øervants. The ≈øtate of that man doth ever at la≈øt prove mo≈øt di≈øhonourable and ba≈øe, that thinkes to enoble him≈øelfe without Chri≈øt. Jo≈øeph brought his brethren, and pre≈øented them to Pharaoh King of Egypt; hee accepted them, bad them dwell in the Gen. 47.6. be≈øt of the land, and commanded that the men of activity among them ≈øhould
be rulers over his catell: through Chri≈øt wee come nigh to the great King of heaven and earth, hee accepts us, hee be≈øtowes his be≈øt ble≈ø≈øings upon us, and makes us ≈øpirituall rulers over all worldly vanities, and our owne affections. Very great is the honour that God di≈øpen≈øeth unto man through Chri≈øt his Sonne.

Mans care to pre≈øerve his honor.And O how great ≈øhould the care of man bee that is thus honoured by Chri≈øt, not to di≈øhonour him≈øelfe, by wallowing like a ≈øwine in the mire and filth of ≈øinne, by bowing downe to the world as Gideons Iud. 7. thou≈øands to the waters, by enthralling him≈øelfe to the Divell and his owne lu≈øts, as ≈øometimes Dalila cut off Samp≈øons Iud. 16. lockes, and made him a ≈ølave to the Phili≈øtines. O man doe not di≈øhonour that nature of thine, which Chri≈øt hath ≈øo honoured, doe not deba≈øe that which Chri≈øt hath exalted, doe not unite and joyne thy ≈øelfe in communion with the Divell, and the dung and dro≈ø≈øe of the world, Chri≈øt having taken mans nature into the unitie of his per≈øon, as a pledge of thy future exaltation; doe not bow downe thy ≈øoule and exalt thy lu≈øt, as Solomon ≈øometimes ≈øaw Eccl. 10.17. ≈øervants on hor≈øe-backe
and Princes walking on foote.

But as Chri≈øt hath honoured thee, Manner how man mu≈øt pre≈øerve his honour. Non e≈øt dig ‚Ä¢ um ut inde exigas honorem unde refugis laborem ≈øo maintaine thy dignity and ≈øpirituall glory, by purging thy ≈øelfe from ≈øinne, as a living ≈øpring doth purge it ≈øelfe from pollution; by contending mightily again≈øt all the oppo≈øitions of grace, as a Souldier in the day of battle; by being indu≈øtrious in the works of holine≈ø≈øe, as hee that labours for great wages: a Chri≈øtians labour is his honour; by ≈øhining as the Sunne with light, by being full as the tree with fruit, by abounding as the ≈øea with waters. As the nature which Chri≈øt hath a≈ø≈øumed abides unchangeably united to the per≈øon of the Sonne; ≈øoIoh. 15.7 abide with Chri≈øt, in attendance on his ordinances, in faith in his promi≈øes, in love to his truth, and in obedience to his precepts: As the a≈ø≈øumed nature is a≈øcended from the earth to heaven, ≈øo rai≈øe thy thoughts and affectionsCol. 3.2. from the things below to the things above; a≈øcend continually by meditation, by faith, by love and longing to the things which are ≈øpirituall: As the a≈ø≈øumed nature hath no ≈øub≈øi≈øtence but in the per≈øon of the Sonne, ≈øo have thou no dependance upon any thing but on Chri≈øt alone; let himP≈øal. 73.15. bee all
in all: And as the a≈ø≈øumed nature is filled with the fulne≈ø≈øe of the Godhead, ≈øo labour more and more to bee filled with the fulne≈ø≈øe of all grace and holine≈ø≈øe; ≈øo ≈øhalt thou maintaine that honour to which Chri≈øt hath exalted thy nature.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Shewing that mans choyce≈øt excellencie con≈øi≈øteth in union with God.
div.p:
THis ≈øheweth us wherein the choyce≈øt excellencie of man con≈øi≈øteth, even in being united unto God, in having God dwelling in his heart. Wherein ≈øtands the excellencie of Chri≈øt as Man, but in having the Godhead dwelling in his fle≈øh, in being a≈ø≈øumed into the unity of the ≈øecond per≈øon? And wherein ≈øtands the excellencie, the glory, and the happine≈ø≈øe of man, but in being reconciled and brought nigh to God, in being entred into a ≈øweet and gracious communion with God? Is it not the excellencie of the branches to bee united to the Vine? of the members to bee united to the head? of the wife to have communion with the
husband? and of the children to have communion with the parent? And what is the excellencie, the joy and comfort of the ≈øoule, but ≈øweet and gracious communion with God in Chri≈øt? Jeru≈øalem, though the joy of the whole earth, plea≈øed not Ab≈øolom unle≈ø≈øe hee might2 Sam. 14.32. ≈øee the face of his father David: The paradi≈øe of the world is but a wilderne≈øs to to the childe of God, unle≈ø≈øe hee ≈øee the face, enjoy the comfortable pre≈øence of God his Father. Whom doth the P≈øalmi≈øt pronounce ble≈ø≈øed? Him that hath communion with Princes in their Courts, with Nobles in their honours, with valiant men in their victories, with rich men in their wealth, voluptuous men in their plea≈øures, or him that hath communion with his God in his ordinances, in his ≈øpirituall comforts?P≈øal. 65.4. Ble≈ø≈øed (≈øaith he) is the man whom thou chu≈øe≈øt, and cau≈øe≈øt to approch unto thee: whom thou chu≈øe≈øt, embracing him with thy love, adopting him for thy ≈øonne, and making him a member of thy Church, and cau≈øe≈øt him to approch unto thee, as a Scholler to thy Schoole, as a friend to thy hou≈øe, as a childe to thy table, as a bride into the bo≈øome of thy
love, to know thy will, to beleeve thy truth, to receive thy grace, and to feele thy love, and to bee ≈øatisfied with the goodne≈ø≈øe of thy hou≈øe, even of thy holy Temple. What is the fruit and end of all the labours of Gods Mini≈øters, but to worke and draw home the ≈øoules of men to God, to the fruition & enjoyment of God, to union and communion with God? All the labour of Eleazar was to bring home Rebecca unto I≈øaac, to e≈øpou≈øe her to I≈øaac: and all the labour of Gods Mini≈øters, his ≈øervants, is to bring men home to Chri≈øt, to e≈øpou≈øe them to Chri≈øt; as Paul ≈øaith, I 2 Cor. 11.2. have e≈øpou≈øed you to one husband. This is the ≈øumme of all, to gather men home to God and Chri≈øt, as Chicken to the Henne, as Sheep unto the Shepheard, as Children to the Parent, that they may bee2 Cor. 5.19. reconciled unto God, made one with God, and have the ble≈ø≈øed enjoyment of God, as their highe≈øt excellency & chiefe≈øt good. And what are the longings of the ≈øoules of holy men who have di≈øcerned Gods beauties, who have ta≈øted Gods loving kindne≈ø≈øe, but the fruition of God in his ordinances, and in his graces?P≈ø. 42.2 My ≈øoul (≈øaith David) thir≈øteth for
God, O when ≈øhall I come & appeare before God! And againe, My ≈øoule P≈ø. 119.20. breaketh for the longings which it hath unto thy judgements at all times. Very vehement and laborious are the de≈øires of Gods ≈øervants after him and his te≈øtimonies; de≈øires which doe even con≈øume and weare out the ≈øtrength and vigour of their ≈øoules; de≈øires of per≈øeverance, longing at all times, in pro≈øperitie and adver≈øitie. The ≈øoule of a good man is re≈øtle≈ø≈øe untill it hath the enjoyment of God and Je≈øus Chri≈øt, nothing el≈øe can content and an≈øwere it: Herein ≈øtands the excellencie, the glory and comfort of it; untill it attaine this it is unquiet.

Union and communion with God makes the ≈øoule flouri≈øh,Benefits of union and communion with God. as the branches by union with the vine. They P≈ø. 92.12 that are planted in the hou≈øe of the Lord, that draw nigh to God, con≈øcionably frequent his word, and are ingrafted into Chri≈øt, they ≈øhall flouri≈øh in the courts of our God, as a watered garden, or a tree planted by the waters ≈øide: this fils the ≈øoule with ≈øpirituall life, with heavenly ≈øen≈øe and motion, as the members which are united to the head:1 Ioh. 5.12. Hee that hath the ≈øonne hath life, power,

goe pre≈øently to the Phy≈øician, with the woman of Shunem wee ≈øaddle the hor≈øe,2 King. 4. and ride in all ha≈øte; if fire bee kindled in the hou≈øe, wee in≈øtantly runne for water to quench it; if a citie be be≈øieged, like the men of Gibeon, Io≈ø. 10.6. wee ≈øpeedily ≈øend for ≈øtrength to remove it; if wee bee rob'd, wee forthwith make hue and cry, that the thiefe may be apprehended: Husbandmen for the earth, Mariners for the ≈øea, Merchants for the Mart, and every Smith ≈øtrikes while the iron is hot: And is it not a ≈øhame that wee, who≈øe ≈øoules are ≈øo dangerou≈øly di≈øea≈øed, an infernall fire burning within us, an armie of unclean ≈øpirits laying ≈øiege again≈øt us, many theeves robbing us of the be≈øt among all jewels, & yet wee move not, ≈øtirre not, ≈øtrive not for deliverance? Wee have the be≈øt ≈øeed to ≈øow, the riche≈øt voyage to make, the chiefe≈øt merchandi≈øe to buy, and yet wee regard not our day, e≈øteeme not the time of our vi≈øitation, entertaine not the proffer which God of his free and abundant mercie doth make. O beloved, con≈øider,

Fir≈øt, how ju≈øt it will bee with God not to heare us in our mi≈øery, if wee refu≈øe to heare him inviting us in the multitude of
his mercie: ≈øhall the ma≈øter heare the ≈øervant reque≈øting, if the ≈øervant regard not the ma≈øter requiring? Remember the words of a dying man, of a dying King, a holy, a wi≈øe King, a man after Gods owne heart, the words of King David to his ≈øonne Solomon, 1 Chron. 28.9. Thou my ≈øonne Solomon, know thou the God of thy father, and ≈øerve him, with a perfect heart, and with a willing minde: for the Lord ≈øearcheth all hearts, and under≈øtandeth all the imaginations of the thoughts: If thou ≈øeeke him, hee will bee found of thee, but if thou for≈øake him hee will ca≈øt thee off for ever.

Secondly, doth not our refu≈øall of mercie when it is offered, cut off all hope of mercie for hereafter? Thirdly, will not our continuance in
≈øinne make our repentance (if ever we doe repent) ≈øo much the more grievous, full of terrour, vexation and angui≈øh? Fourthly, will God be well plea≈øed that we ≈øhall ≈øpend all the flower and ≈øtrength of our time in Satans ≈øervice, and when wee are old, and can ≈øerve ≈øin no longer, come crowd and thru≈øt our ≈øelves into his ≈øervice?

Fifthly, doe not wee hereby lo≈øe much ≈øpirituall riches, ble≈ø≈øed communion and acquaintance with God, comfortable a≈ø≈øurance of joy and glory in the heavens, that comfort, peace, plea≈øure, rejoycing, contentment which infinitely ≈øurpa≈ø≈øeth all the contentment in the world? O therfore let us not any longer delay our conver≈øion, put off our repentance, neglect the day of our vi≈øitation, let us not be like Jeru≈øalem, ≈øtrangers to the things belonging to our peace; but let us thinke upon the Lords patheticall and manifold expo≈øtulations,

Repent and turne your ≈øelves from all your tran≈øgre≈øsions, make you a new heart and a new ≈øpirit; for why will yee dye, O hou≈øe of I≈ørael? Call to minde al≈øo, and thinke ≈øeriou≈øly upon the Lords free and gracious invitations,Ier. 3.22. bidding us by the Prophet, Turne, O back-≈øliding children, and I will heale your back-≈ølidings. Zech. 1.3. And againe, Turne yee unto mee, Mat. 11.28. and I will turne to you. And, Come to mee all yee that be heavie loaden, and I will refre≈øh you. Thinke on this, and Remember your Creator in the dayes of your youth: Eccle≈ø. 12.1. Remember him as a Maker to depend upon him, as a Father to love him, as a Ma≈øter to feare him, as a King to obey him, as a Friend to rejoyce in him, as a Shield to defend you, a Store-hou≈øe to mini≈øter all fulne≈ø≈øe to you. And as the Angell charged Lot, Gen. 19.17. E≈øcape for thy life, looke not behinde thee, neither ≈øtay in all the plaine, e≈øcape to the mountaines le≈øt thou bee con≈øumed: ≈øo let mee charge, exhort, intreat, per≈øwade every per≈øon that tenders his owne
everla≈øting peace, glory, comfort, to ha≈øten out of the Sodome of ≈øinne, to e≈øcape from his uncleanne≈ø≈øe, not to looke back with love or liking upon any way which God hath forbidden, le≈øt his con≈øuming wrath ≈øeize upon him, but ≈øhine more and more like the Sunne unto the perfect day: Goe forward, like a good traveller; bee filled with all goodne≈ø≈øe, as the ≈øea with waters, and you ≈øhall have a re≈øting place in Sion, drinke of the rivers which ≈øhall fill your ≈øoules with the choyce≈øt plea≈øures, and bee more glorious then the Sunne for ever in the heavens.
