div.p:
THE comming of the Sunne is joyous to him that hath been long in darkne≈ø≈øe; the comming of the Dove with an Olive branch, was comfortable to Noah after he had been to≈ø≈øed divers dayes upon the deluge; the re-appearing of the Starre to the Wi≈øe men, made them exceeding joyfull: And ≈øuch is the comming of the Lord Je≈øus to the ≈øoules of his ≈øervants, when they have ≈øate in darkne≈ø≈øe, and have had no light; when they have been to≈ø≈øed upon the deluge of many troubles, and have had no footing for their ≈øoules, no haven wherein to repo≈øe them≈øelves; when they have wandred, like travellers, in this earthly wilderne≈øs without a guide;
then have their ≈øoules longed after Chri≈øt Je≈øus,Mal. 4.2. that Sunne of righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, who appeareth with healing in his wings; Numb. 24 17. I≈øa. 9.6. that Star of Iacob, who giveth light to them that are in darkne≈ø≈øe; that Prince of Peace, who brings the olive branch of peace to ≈øoules that are perpl ‚Ä¢ xed. Se ‚Ä¢ ≈øe of di≈øtre≈ø≈øes doth marvellou≈øly ≈øweete ‚Ä¢ the Lord Je≈øus, and fill the ≈øoule with longings after the fruition of his favours. When the Gibeonites were be≈øieged with the Amoriti≈øh Princes,Jo≈ø. 10.6. they ≈øent to Io≈øua, ≈øaying, Slacke not thine hand from thy ≈øervants, come up to us quickly, and ≈øave us, and helpe us: when our ≈øoules are be≈øieged with an armie of troubles, to≈ø≈øed upon the tempe≈øt of manifold afflictions, when no Captaine can fight for us, no anchor can ≈øtay us, no friend can comfort us, no ≈øhield and buckler defend us, no Phy≈øician heale us; then wee long for Chri≈øts gracious pre≈øence, then wee make earne≈øt ≈øuit for his powerfull a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, then we ≈øay, Come Lord Ie≈øus.

The≈øe words are almo≈øt the la≈øt words of the whole word of God, the la≈øt words (as I have heard) uttered by this decea≈øed partie, which gave mee occa≈øion at this time (being the la≈øt office wee are to performe
towards him) to treat of them, to commend them to your con≈øideration, the better to prepare you all for your la≈øt reckoning, to fit you for the day of your di≈ø≈øolution, to per≈øwade and move you to labour for ≈øuch faith, ≈øuch love, ≈øuch repentance, ≈øuch competencie of all ≈øaving graces, that at the houre of your departure out of this earthly pilgrimage, you may bee able, as friends and ≈øervants, as the ≈øpou≈øe and bride, as ≈øonnes and daughters of God and Chri≈øt Je≈øus, to ≈øay, Come Lord Ie≈øus.

The words are a holy and fervent wi≈øh and de≈øire, vote, and prayer of Iohn the Evangeli≈øt, in his owne, and in the name of all the faithfull, for the ≈øpeedy, gracious, and glorious comming of the Lord Je≈øus. Iohn the Evangeli≈øt was Chri≈øts beloved Di≈øciple, Joh. 13.23 one who in the dayes of his fle≈øh had repo≈øed him≈øelfe in Chri≈øts bo≈øome, and here de≈øires Chri≈øts comming. By how much the neerer communion wee have now with Chri≈øt by grace and holine≈ø≈øe,Note. by ≈øo much the more his ≈øecond comming is de≈øired by us: Grace and holine≈ø≈øe e≈øtates us in the condition of ≈øonnes and daughters to God the Father; in the
condition of Bride & Spou≈øe to Chri≈øt Je≈øus, intitle us to all Gods promi≈øes, ≈øweeten all Gods te≈øtimonies, make all Gods ordinances the ≈øavour of life to life unto us, ≈øettle us in the ≈øen≈øe of Gods loving kindne≈ø≈øe, in the a≈ø≈øurance of the forgivene≈ø≈øe of all our ≈øinnes and offences, and ≈øo make the ≈øecond comming of Chri≈øt mo≈øt de≈øirous. Want of holine≈ø≈øe deprives the ≈øouls of men of all the ≈øweet and heavenly comforts ari≈øing from the ≈øecond comming of Chri≈øt Je≈øus. The un≈øanctified man that ≈øayes, Come Lord Ie≈øus, prayes God to ha≈øten his eternall vengeance: hee that without grace prayes for Chri≈øts comming, beggs his owne ≈øpeedy and finall de≈øtruction. Labour therfore in the dayes of your life for holine≈ø≈øe, that you may with comfort in the houre of your death ≈øay, Come Lord Ie≈øus. Iohn the Evangeli≈øt had ≈øeen, in a vi≈øion, the Churches affliction, the adver≈øaries in≈øultation, the future felicitie prepared for the one, and the future calamity provided for the other, and Chri≈øt made glorious in both: and therefore hee prayes, Come Lord Je≈øus. No man rightly de≈øires Chri≈øts comming,Note. but he that hath a≈ø≈øurance of the good and
benefite of his coming: To them the day of Chri≈øt is as the day of harve≈øt to the hu≈øbandman, as the day of deliverance to the pri≈øoner, as the day of coronation to the King, as the day of wedlocke to the bride; a day of triumph and exaltation, a day of freedome and con≈øolation, a day of re≈øt and ≈øatisfaction; to them the Lord Je≈øus is all ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe,Cant 1.2, 3. as wine to the palate, and oyntment to the no≈øtrill, ≈øaith Solomon. Mel in ore, melos in aure, Iubilus in corde. Hony in the mouth (≈øaith Bernard) mu≈øick in the eare, and a jubilee in the heart. Get a≈ø≈øurance of Chri≈øts comming as a Ran≈øomer to redeeme you, as a Conquerour to ≈øubdue all your enemies under you, as a Friend to comfort you, as a King to honour you, as a Phy≈øician to heale you, as a Bridegroome to marry you; and then ≈øhall you with confidence and boldne≈ø≈øe, with joy and gladne≈ø≈øe, with vehement and holy longings, ≈øay, Come Lord Ie≈øus.

In the words there is Motus & Movens, 1. a Motion, and 2. a Mover: the motion, Come; the mover, the Lord Ie≈øus. Fir≈øt of the motion, wherein is the Modus, the manner of uttering the≈øe words, by way of vote, wi≈øh and ≈øupplication; and the
Genus, or kinde of motion, Come. The Evangeli≈øt de≈øireth Chri≈øt to come: Chri≈øt, as God, is every where, and in re≈øpect of his e≈ø≈øence doth neither goe nor come, his divine e≈ø≈øence being free from all motion and mutation: yet, as God, hee commeth by his Mini≈øters, as a King by his Emba≈ø≈øadours; by his ordinances, as a Prince by his lawes; by his gifts and graces, as the Sunne by his beames and light; by his ca≈øtigations and afflictions, as a man of warre by his armies; by his favours and ble≈ø≈øings, as a friend by his love-tokens: As Man, he came once by incarnation, taking our fle≈øh upon him, and ≈øhall come at la≈øt as a glorious and dreadful Judge to render to every man according to his worke: and in this re≈øpect principally doth the Evangeli≈øt here de≈øire him to come; to come as a Judge to ≈øubvert Antichri≈øt, to ≈øubdue the kingdome of ≈øinne and Satan, to render to all ungodly men according to their doing; to come as Redeemer, to bring a full and finall deliverance to all beleevers, to all contrite and broken hearted ≈øinners from all evils, and to conferre upon them all peace and bli≈ø≈øe, all glory and happine≈ø≈øe, this being the de≈øire and prayer of all the
faithfull, of all that have received the ≈øpirit of adoption: We may hence learne, that

It is the unfained de≈øire of Gods faithfull ≈øervants,
Doct.
to have the full fruition of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus. 2 Sam. 14 32. Ab≈øolon ≈øo de≈øired to ≈øee the face of David the King and his father, that he valued it above his life: the Lords ≈øervants ≈øo de≈øire to ≈øee the face of Chri≈øt their King and Redeemer, and to have the full enjoyment of his comfortable and glorious pre≈øence, that nothing is ≈øo pretious in their apprehen≈øions, valued and e≈øteemed by them above the deare≈øt earthly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, above the choyce≈øt worldly comforts,Can. 1.3. P≈øa. 63.3. above wine which maketh glad the heart, above the increa≈øe of corne and wine, the joy of the rich; above life the choyce≈øt pearle, and deere≈øt trea≈øure in natures clo≈øet. If the dawning of the day bee ≈øo joyous, how much more plea≈øant is the Sunne ri≈øing? If the fir≈øt fruits be ≈øo acceptable, how much more abundantly joyful ‚Ä¢ is the full vintage?
